creditline: Lent by Richard and Diana Rose
description: silver-colored finish; circular base; vertical rod attached to base; mouth piece mounted on top of rod, angle is adjustable; cradle arm attaches at side; hand-held ear piece has long, attached (wooden?) handle; ear piece hangs vertically in cradle; ear piece attached to circular base with green, cloth cord
dimension: 11 3/4 x 7 x 6 in. (29.85 x 17.78 x 15.24 cm) (with ear piece in cradle)
text: Commonly called the "oil can" phone due to its suggestive profile, this "classic candlestick" form derives from the practical necessity of keeping the transmitter upright.  However, the apparent simplicity of the design is misleading, for the telephone requires a separate bell set (containing induction coil, capacitor and ringer) in order to operate.  The nickname "candlestick" is a modern term; at the time these phones were manufactured they were called "desk stands."
title: "Desk Stand" rotary-dial desk phone
